WVHERE as not loÃÑg ≈øithens a boke came forthe in our and all oure coun≈øailes names, whyche bothe coÃÑteyned many cau≈øes, why we refu≈øed the Councylle, than by the by≈øhoppe of Romes v≈øurped power fyr≈øte indycted atte Mantua, to be kepte the .xxiii. daye of May, after proroged to Nouembre, noo place appoynted where it ≈øhulde be kepte. And where as the ≈øame boke dothe ≈øufficiently proue, that our cau≈øe coulde take no hurt,
neyther with any thynge doone or decreed in ≈øuche a company of addicte men to one ≈øecte, nor in any other councill callyd by his v≈øurped power, we thynke it nothynge nece≈ø≈øarie, ≈øo ofte to make newe prote≈øtations, as the by≈øhoppe of Rome and his courtes by ≈øubtiltie & craft, do inuent ways to mock the worlde by newe preten≈øed general councilles. Yet not with≈øtandynge bicau≈øe that ≈øome thynges haue nowe occured, eyther vpon occa≈øion giuen vs, by chaunge of the place, or els through other con≈øiderations, whiche nowe beynge knowen to the worlde, maye doo moche good, we thought we ≈øhulde do, but euen as that loue enfor≈øeth vs, whiche we owe vnto Chri≈øtis faythe and relygion, to adde this epi≈øtell: And yet we prote≈øt, that we neither put forth
that boke, neyther yet we wold this epi≈øtle to be ≈øet afore it, that therby we ≈øhulde ≈øeme le≈ø≈øe to de≈øyre a generall Councille, thanne any other prince or potentate, but rather more de≈øirous of it, ≈øo it were free for all partes, and vniuer≈øal. And further we de≈øyre all good princis, potentatis, and people, to e≈øteme and think that no prince wold more willyngly be pre≈øent at ≈øuche a council than we, ≈øuche a one, we meane, as we ≈øpeake of in our prote≈øtation, made concernynge the councill of Mantua. Truely as our forefathers inuented nothynge more holyer than generalle Councilles, v≈øed as they ought to be, ≈øo there is almo≈øte noothing, that way do more hurt to the Chry≈øtian common welthe, to the faith, to our religion, than general councils, if they be abu≈øed to lukes,
to gaynes, to the e≈øtably≈øhement of errours. They be called generall, & euen by theyr name do admony≈ø≈øhe vs, that all Chri≈øten men, which do di≈øcent in any opinion, may in them openly, frankly, and without feare of puny≈øhement or di≈øplea≈øure, ≈øay their mynde. For ≈øeing ≈øuch thinges as are decreed in generall councils, touche egally all men that gyue a≈ø≈øent thervnto, it is mete that euery man, maye boldely ≈øaye there, that he thynketh. And verylye we ≈øuppo≈øe, that it ought not to be callyd a generall councylle, where alonly tho≈øe men are harde, whiche are determyned for euer, in all poyntes, to defende the popy≈ø≈øhe parte, and to arme them ≈øelfe to fyght in the by≈ø≈øhoppe of Romes quarelle, though it were agayn≈øte god and his ≈øcriptures. It is no generall Councill,
neyther it oughte to be callyd generall, where the ≈øame menne be onely aduocates & aduer≈øaries, the ≈øame accu≈øed and iuges. No it is again≈øt the lawe of nature, eyther that we ≈øhulde conde≈øcende to ≈øo vnre≈øonable a lawe agayn≈øte our ≈øelfes, eyther that we ≈øhulde ≈øuffre our ≈øelfes to be lefte without all defence, and beinge oppre≈ø≈øed with greatte≈øt iniuries, to haue no refuge to ≈øuccour our≈øelfes at. The bi≈øhop of Rome and his, be our great enmies, as we and all the worlde maye welle perceyue by his doinges. He de≈øyreth nothynge more than our hurte, and the de≈øtruction of our realme: doo not we than violate the iudgement of nature, yf we gyue hym power and auctoritie to be our iudge? His pretended honour fyr≈øte gotten by ≈øuper≈øtition, after encrea≈øed by violence,
and other wayes, as euylle as that: his power ≈øette vppe by preten≈øe of religion, in dede, bothe agayn≈øt religion, and al≈øo contrary to the worde of god: his primacye, borne by the ignorancie of the worlde, noury≈øhed by the ambition of by≈øhops of Rome, defended by places of Scripture, fal≈øely vnder≈øtande. The≈øe .iii. thynges we ≈øay, whiche are fallen with vs, and are like to fall in other realmes ≈øhortly, ≈øhall they not be e≈øtably≈øhed agein, if he maye decyde our cau≈øe as hym ly≈øteth? If he maye at his plea≈øure oppre≈ø≈øe a cau≈øe moo≈øte rightuou≈øe, and ≈øet vp his, mo≈øte againe truth? Certaynely he is very blynde, that ≈øeeth not, what ende we maye loke for of our controuer≈øies, if ≈øuch our ennemye maye gyue the ≈øentence. We de≈øyre, if it were in anye wy≈øe
po≈ø≈øible, a council, where ≈øome hope may be, that tho≈øe thynges, ≈øhal be re≈øtored, whiche nowe being deprauate, are lyke, if they be not amended, to be the vtter ruine of chri≈øten religion. And as we do de≈øyre ≈øuche a councyll, and thynke it mete, that all men in all theyr prayers, ≈øhulde craue and de≈øyre it of god: euen ≈øoo we think it perteyneth vnto our offyce, to prouyde bothe that the≈øe popi≈øhe ≈øubtilties hurte none of our ≈øubiectes, and al≈øo to admony≈øhe other Chri≈øten princis, that the by≈øhoppe of Rome maye not by theyr con≈øent abu≈øe the auctoritie of kinges, eyther to the extinguy≈øhing of the true preaching of ≈øcripture (that nowe beginneth to ≈øpring, to grow, and ≈øpred abrode, either to the troublyng of princis liberties, to the dimyni≈øhinge of kynges auctorities,
and to the great blemy≈ø≈øhe of theyr princely maie≈øtie. We dout nothing but a reder not parciall, wyll ≈øoone approue ≈øuche thinges, as we write in the treati≈øe folowynge, not ≈øoo moche for oure excu≈øe, as that the worlde may perceyue bothe the ≈øondrye deceytes, craftes, & ≈øubtilties of the papi≈øtes, and al≈øo, how moch we de≈øyre, that controuer≈øies in relygion maye ones be taken awaye. All that we ≈øaid there of Mantua, maye here well be ≈øpoken of Vincence. They do almo≈øte agree in all poyntes. Neyther it is lyke, that there woll be any more at this Concille at Vincence, than were the la≈øt yere at Mantua. Trewelye he is worthy to be deceyued, that beynge twy≈øe mocked, woll not beware the thyrde tyme. If any this la≈øte yere made forthe towarde Mantua, and
beinge halfe on theyr waye, thanne perceyued, that they hadde taken vppon them that iourney in vaine, we do not thynke them ≈øo fooly≈øhe, that they woll hereafter ryde farre oute of towne to be mocked. The tyme al≈øo, and the ≈øtate of thynges is ≈øuche, that matters of Religyon maye rather nowe be broughte farther in trouble, as other thynges are, than be commodiou≈øely intreated of, and decyded. For where as in maner the hole worlde is after ≈øuch ≈øorte troublyd with warres, ≈øo incombred with the greatte preparacyons that the Turke maketh, can there be any manne ≈øo agayn≈øte the ≈øetlynge of relygyon, that he wolle thynke this tyme mete for a general Councill? vndoubtedly it is mete that ≈øuch controuer≈øies, as we haue with the by≈øhoppe of Rome, be taken
as they are, that is much greatter, than that they maye eyther be di≈øcu≈ø≈øed in this ≈øoo trouble≈øome a tyme, or elles be commytted vnto proctours, without oure greate ieoperdie, all be it the tyme were neuer ≈øo quiete. What other prynces wyl do, we can not tell, but we wyl neither leaue our realme at this tyme, neyther we wyl tru≈øte any proctour with our cau≈øe, wherin the holle ≈øtay and welthe of our realme ≈øtandeth, but rather we wyll be atte the handlynge therof our ≈øelfe. For except both an other iudge be agreed vpon for tho≈øe matters, and al≈øo a place more commodiou≈øe be prouided, for the debating of our cau≈øes, all be it all other thynges were as we wolde haue theym, yet maye we laufully refu≈øe to come or ≈øende any to this pretended Councyl. We wol
in noo ca≈øe make hym our arbyter, whiche not many yeres pa≈øte, oure cau≈øe not hard, gaue ≈øenteÃÑce agein≈øt vs. We woll that ≈øuche doctrine, as we, followyng the ≈øcripture, do profe≈ø≈øe, ritely to be examinid, di≈øcu≈ø≈øid, and to be brought to ≈øcripture, as to the onely touche ≈øtoone of true lernynge. We wyll not ≈øuffre them to be aboly≈ø≈øhed, ere euer they be dy≈øcu≈ø≈øed, ne to be oppre≈ø≈øid, before they be knowen: moche le≈ø≈øe we wyl ≈øuffre them to be troden downe beinge ≈øo clerely trewe. No, as there is no iote in ≈øcripture, but we wolle defende it, thoughe it were with ieoperdie of oure lyfe, and perylle of this our Realme: ≈øoo is there noo thynge, that doth oppre≈ø≈øe this doctrine, or ob≈øcure it, but we woll be at continualle warre therwith. As we haue abrogated all olde popi≈øhe
traditions in this our realme, whiche eyther dyd helpe his tyrannye, or increa≈øe his pride: ≈øo if the grace of God for≈øake vs not, we will wel fore≈øee, that no newe naughty traditions be made with our con≈øente, to bynde vs or our realme. If men wyll not be wyllyngly blinde, they ≈øhall ea≈øily ≈øee euen by a due and euident profe in re≈øon, though grace dothe not yet by the worde of Chri≈øt enter into them, howe ≈ømall thauctoritie of the by≈øhop of Rome is, by the laufull denyall of the Duke of Mantua for the place. For yf the by≈ø≈øhoppe of Rome dydde erne≈øtly intende to kepe a councyll at Mantua, and hath power by the lawe of God, to calle princis to what place hym lyketh: why hathe he not al≈øo auctoritie, to cho≈øe what place hym ly≈øteth? The By≈ø≈øhop cho≈øe Mantua,
the Duke kepte hym out of it. If Paule the by≈øhoppe of Romes auctoritie be ≈øo great, as he pretendeth, why coulde not he compel Federicus, Duke of Mantua, that the Councylle myghte be kept there? The duke wolde not ≈øuffre it. No, he forbadde hym his towne. Howe chaunceth it, that here excommunicacyons flye not not abroode? Why dothe he not puny≈ø≈øhe this Duke? Why is his power, that was wonte to be more than fulle, here emptie? wonte to be more than all, here nothynge? Dothe he not call men in vayne to a Councylle, yf they that comme at his callynge, be excluded the place, to the whiche he callethe theym? Maye not Kynges iu≈øtely refu≈øe to come at his call, whan the Duke of Mantua may denye him the place, that he cho≈øeth? If other
prynces order hym as the Duke of Mantua hathe doone, what place ≈øhall be lefte hym, where he maye kepe his generall Councill? Again. If Prynces haue gyuen hym this auctoritie, to calle a Councille, is hit not nece≈ø≈øarye, that they gyue hym al≈øo, all tho≈øe thynges, withoute the whiche he canne not exercy≈øe that his power? Shall he call men, and woll ye let hym fynde no place to calle them vnto? Truely he is not wonte to appoynte one of his owne Cyties, a place to keepe the council in. No, the good man is ≈øo faythefull and frendely towarde other, that ≈øeldome he de≈øyreth princes to be his ge≈øtis. And admitte he ≈øhulde calle vs to one of his cityes, ≈øhulde we ≈øafely walke within the walles of ≈øuch our enmies towne? were if mete for vs there to dy≈øcu≈ø≈øe
controuer≈øyes of Relygyon, or to kepe vs out of our ennemyes trappes? meete to ≈øtudye for the defence of ≈øuche doctrine as we profe≈ø≈øe, or rather howe we myghte in ≈øuche a thronge of perylles be in ≈øauegarde of oure lyfe? Well, in this one acte the by≈øhoppe of Rome hath declared, that he hath none auctorytye vppon places in other mennes domynyons, and therfore yf he promy≈øe a Councille in any of tho≈øe, he promy≈øeth that that is in other man to perfourme, and ≈øo may he deceyue vs agayne. Nowe if he calle vs to one of his owne townes, we be afrayde to be at ≈øuche an ho≈øtes table. we ≈øaye, better to ry≈øe a hungred, then to goo then≈øe with oure bellyes fulle. But they ≈øaye, the place is founde, we neede noo more ≈øeke where the Councill ≈øhall
be kepte. As who ≈øaythe, that, that chaunced at Mantua, maye not al≈øo chaunce at Vyncence. And as thoughe it were very lyke, that the Venecians, menne of ≈øuche wy≈øedome, ≈øhoulde not bothe fore≈øee, and feare al≈øo that, that the wy≈øe Duke of Mantua ≈øemed to feare. Certes, whanne we thynke vppon the ≈øtate, that the Venecians be in nowe, hit ≈øeemeth noo verye lykely thynge, that they woll eyther leaue Vincence, theyr Cytye, to ≈øo many nations, withoute ≈øome great garri≈øon of ≈øouldyers, or elles that they beinge elles where, ≈øo ≈øore charged allredy, wyll nowe nory≈ø≈øhe an armye there. And if they wolde, dothe not Paulus hym ≈øelfe graunt, that it ≈øhulde be an euyll pre≈øydent, and an euyll exaumple, to haue an armed Councille? How ≈øo euer it ≈øhal
be, we mo≈øte hartely de≈øyre you, that ye woll vouche≈øafe, to rede tho≈øe thinges, that we wrote this la≈øt yere touchynge the Mantuan Councille. For we nothynge doubte, but you, of youre equytye, wyll ≈øtande on our ≈øyde agayn≈øte theyr ≈øubtyltye and fraudes, and iudge (except we be deceyued) that we in this bu≈øyne≈ø≈øe, neyther gaue ≈øo moche to oure affectyons, neyther withoute greate and moo≈øte iu≈øte cau≈øes, refu≈øed theyr Councilles, theyr Cen≈øures, and Decrees. Whyther the≈øe our wrytynges plea≈øe all menne, or noo, we thynke, we oughte not to pa≈ø≈øe moche. No, if that, that indifferentely is wrytten of vs, may plea≈øe indifferente reders, our defyre is accomply≈ø≈øhed. The fal≈øe and my≈øtakyng of thynges, by men parcyall, ≈øhall moue vs nothynge,
orelles very lytell. If we haue ≈øaid aughte agayn≈øte the deceytes of the By≈ø≈øhop of Rome, that maye ≈øeme ≈øpoken to ≈øharpely, We praye you, impute it to the hatredde we bare vnto vyces, and not to any euyll wyll that we bare hym. Noo, that he, and all his, maye perceyue, that we are rather at ≈øtryfe with his vyces, than with hym, and his: oure prayer is, bothe that it maye plea≈øe god, at the la≈øte to open their eyes, to make ≈øofte theyr harde hartes, and that they ones maye with vs (theyr owne glorye ≈øet aparte) ≈øtudy to ≈øet forth the euerla≈øtynge glorye, of the euerla≈øtynge God.

¬∂ Thus myghtye Emperoure Fare ye mo≈øte hartely well, and ye Chri≈øten Prynces, the pylors and ≈øtaye of Chri≈øtendome, Fare ye hartely well. Al≈øo all ye, what people ≈øo
